title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, [17? march 1873]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [17? March 1873]
text: My dear waltWalt its another mondayMonday morning and eddEdd and me is alone georgeGeorge has gone to brooklynBrooklyn and Lou is going to philadelphPhiladelphia i wish you was here with me to day we would have some good strong tea for dinner georgeGeorge has gone to see about getting the brooklyBrooklyn work and take out a small sum of money from the bank for the man to begin his house or Lou sLou's as she calls it) i should much like to have somebody to talk with i dontdon't hear much but house and money if they could build and keep all the money in the bank it would be good the man is to build it very cheap georgeGeorge thinks he will lose by iti received your letter saturdaySaturday dear waltWalt i am glad you are improving although slowly it is tedious to stay in so long i know by experience i havent been out except next door in ten weeks this street has been so full of ice and there is quite a quantity of snow in it yet but i shall try to go out soon i have been better of the rheumatism this winter untilluntil a week or so ago i got quite lame in my knees so i could hardly get down stairs but i think i took cold going out to the privy getting my feet damp as the water stands in the path nearly all the time but every thing must be kept so scientific here i dontdon't know sometimes how it is i hope there will never be any thing to annoy or disturb the manager i think sometimssometimes a person can be to particular Lou aintain't so nice about any thing but the appearance of the house that seems to be her hobby she has her girls come to see her quite often girls she used to work with they have to all be up here sometimes i dontdon't feel like having them but there is no where else for them but in the kichenkitchen we had five here yesterday not all girls but 3 went away but one girl and her beau staidstayed till 10 oclock)well waltWalt i beleivebelieve that will doodo for gossip) poor jeffJeff i want to write to him to day but i hardly know what to write to him i have the letter from hattieHattie poor little girls i want to see them but i dontdon't know when i ever shall i dontdon't think it would doodo to invite them here to stay) i thought by hattysHatty's letter maybeymaybe they didentdidn't like their new home but your letter says you think they are satisfied hattieHattie didentdidn't say they was dissattisfieddissatisfied but she said the last few weeks seemed like a dream to her of course no place can be like home to them poor matt it seems as if i can hardly realize she is gone as her picture hangs here and looks so much like life it brings the tears to my eyes but i seldom speak of her i think walterWalter dear you and me felt the loss more than any one else except her family of courscourse Jeff feels it more than any one else can but time will asswageassuage in some measurmeasure if it wasentwasn't for that we couldentcouldn't live througthrough our troubles you must write walterWalter deadear as often as you can) will you have to get some one to write for you walterWalter or will the work make no difference dontdon't worry walterWalter dear Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [17? March 1873]
